text.p: Submarine builder Electric Boat Corp., a unit of General Dynamics Corp., said Tuesday it will rehire 130 workers at its shipyard in Quonset Point, Rhode Island.
A company spokesman told Reuters the shipyard had laid off too many workers in recent years.
"We are looking to rehire 130 people, mostly welders, shipfitters and steel fabricators," Electric Boat spokesman Neil Ruenzel said.
"Our scheduled workload is a little higher than we had anticipated."
Employment at the company's Quonset Point shipyard has shrunk to about 1,000 workers from 5,500 in 1985, Ruenzel said.
In the face of declining U.S. defense expenditures, the company's total employment has dwindled to 10,000 from 25,000 over the same period, he said.
Electric Boat has about 9,000 employees at its Groton, Conn., shipyard.
Ruenzel said more layoffs were likely in Groton in several more weeks, after the company delivers its final Trident submarine to the U.S. government.
Ruenzel said the reductions would not be major. He did not elaborate.
